title: 114_s1616
content: The Act titled "Saving Federal Dollars Through Better Use of Government Purchase and Travel Cards Act of 2015" defines terms like "improper payment" and "questionable transaction." It also defines "strategic sourcing" as a way to analyze and modify spending patterns to improve performance. The Act aims to expand the use of data analytics. The Act aims to develop a strategy for expanding the use of data analytics in managing government purchase and travel charge card programs to identify questionable transactions and recover improper payments. Developing purchase and travel card metrics and benchmarks for high-risk activities to assist agencies in oversight, as required by the Government Charge Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2012. Creating a library of analytics tools and data sources for Federal agencies to use, including inspectors general. SEC. 4. GUIDANCE ON IMPROVING INFORMATION SHARING TO CURB IMPROPER PAYMENTS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget, in consultation with relevant agencies, will issue guidance on improving information sharing to curb improper payments within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. This guidance will require federal agencies to identify high-risk activities, communicate them to appropriate management levels, and review reports from charge card-issuing banks on questionable transaction activity. The Director will issue guidance on improving information sharing to prevent improper payments, requiring federal agencies to identify high-risk activities and share information on questionable transactions. This includes sharing information with the General Services Administration Office of Charge Card Management and other relevant officials. Additional requirements may be included as determined appropriate by the Director. SEC. 5. INTERAGENCY CHARGE CARD DATA MANAGEMENT GROUP. Establishment of a purchase and travel charge card data management group by the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Office of Management and Budget to develop best practices related to charge card-issuing banks, review of accounts payable information, and identifying opportunities for charge card usage. The purchase and travel charge card data management group will meet regularly for three years and include agencies specified in the Government Charge Card Abuse Prevention Act of 2012, as well as others identified by the Administrator and Director. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The General Services Administration and Federal agencies must submit reports to Congress on the implementation of the Act, including metrics for reducing improper payments and improving card-based payment utilization. The Office of Management and Budget will also submit a report to Congress. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a consolidated report to Congress on agency activities to implement the Act. The Administrator of General Services will also submit a report to Congress identifying additional savings opportunities for government agencies under the Federal charge card programs. The Senate passed S. 1616 on December 16, 2015, to identify and prevent improper payments and strategic sourcing opportunities by reviewing Federal agency charge card usage.
